newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Taiwan, S.Africa start talks on future ties.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan, S.Africa start talks on future ties.

text.p: Taiwanese Foreign Minister John Chang said on Sunday patience would be needed in shaping a new relationship with South Africa which is breaking off diplomatic ties in favour of Beijing.

"We had a very good meeting," Chang told a news conference after talks with his South African counterpart Alfred Nzo in Pretoria. "These are the first negotiations on arrangements for our future relations."
President Nelson Mandela announced in November that South Africa would scrap diplomatic recognition of Taiwan, regarded by Beijing as a renegade province.

Chang said he was optimistic that the two countries would find a solution which would satisfy Taiwanese business leaders who have invested heavily in South Africa and which would enable Taiwan to resume suspended aid projects.
He said the three hours of talks with Nzo were candid, frank, constructive and useful, but added: "We did not reach any concrete conclusions or reasonable consensus on many issues."
Chang said he had proposed that future relations take into account, among other things, reality, continuity, morality and legality.
"We stated that the present negotiations would be long and both sides had better be patient," he said.
Nzo declined to speak to reporters after the meeting but Chang said he believed the South African minister was pleased with the talks.
About 280 Taiwanese factories in South Africa employing 35,000 people have begun a series of one-day stoppages to protest at Pretoria's decision to cut ties by the end of the year.
